metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

generationDetails.description: Each lesson generated as many valid questions as possible

questions.question: Which layer of Earth is mostly liquid metal and generates Earth’s magnetic field?

answers.content: Crust
answers.explanation: The crust is solid rock and soil.

answers.content: Mantle
answers.explanation: The mantle is mostly solid/semi-solid rock.

answers.content: Outer core
answers.explanation: The outer core is a molten layer of iron and nickel whose convection creates Earth’s magnetic field.

answers.content: Inner core
answers.explanation: The inner core is solid due to immense pressure.

questions.question: Why does Earth’s inner core remain solid even though it is approximately as hot as the surface of the Sun?

answers.content: Because it is made of rock rather than metal
answers.explanation: Both the outer and inner core are made mainly of metal.

answers.content: Immense pressure at Earth’s centre keeps the metal atoms locked in place
answers.explanation: The crushing pressure is greater than the melting effect of the high temperature.

answers.content: There is no heat source in the inner core
answers.explanation: Heat is generated by radioactive decay and residual heat of formation.

answers.content: The mantle cools it rapidly
answers.explanation: Heat transfer through the mantle is very slow; cooling is not the reason.

questions.question: List the four main layers of Earth in order from the outside moving inward.

answers.content: Crust, mantle, outer core, inner core
answers.explanation: This is the accepted sequence of Earth’s layers.

questions.question: Explain how convection currents in the mantle contribute to changes on Earth’s surface such as volcanic eruptions.

answers.content: Heat causes semi-solid mantle rock to rise, cool, and sink in slow convection currents. These currents move tectonic plates and allow magma to reach the surface, leading to volcanic eruptions.
answers.explanation: Mantle convection is the driving mechanism for plate motion and related surface activity.

questions.question: Draw and label a cross-section model of Earth. Your diagram must: • show crust, mantle, outer core, inner core • use a different colour for each layer • include a brief annotation (one sentence) describing temperature or composition for each layer.

answers.content: Drawing includes all four correctly labelled layers with colour key and annotations for temperature/composition.
answers.explanation: Full marks if all criteria met; partial credit if one element is missing or incorrect.

questions.question: What is the main cause of most earthquakes?

answers.content: A sudden release of energy when tectonic plates that were stuck suddenly slip
answers.explanation: Stress builds along plate boundaries until the plates jerk past one another, releasing energy as seismic waves.

answers.content: A gradual sinking of Earth’s mantle
Changes in the Moon’s gravitational pull

questions.question: In the Mars-bar model used in class, which part of the chocolate bar represented Earth’s crust?

answers.content: The thin chocolate coating on the outside
answers.explanation: The hard chocolate layer models the rigid outer crust that cracks when plates collide.

answers.content: The caramel layer
The nougat centre

questions.question: What is meant by the term “landscape” as used in this lesson?

answers.content: Any natural or built feature in a particular area of Earth’s surface
answers.explanation: Landscape includes mountains, rivers, buildings, roads and other visible features of an area.

questions.question: Which of the following was one effect of the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake in Japan?

answers.content: Parts of the coastline were uplifted above sea level
answers.explanation: The land rose, changing the shape of the shoreline.

answers.content: A new volcano formed on the peninsula
Glaciers melted rapidly

questions.question:
Complete the sentence using the causal connective “so”.
“The earthquake struck, so …”

answers.content: … the land rose up and changed the shape of the coastline.
answers.explanation: Answers should show cause and effect, e.g. “… so buildings collapsed,” or “… so cracks opened in the road.”

questions.question: When the epicentre of an earthquake is under the ocean, what additional natural hazard can be produced?

answers.content: A tsunami
answers.explanation: Seafloor movement displaces water, generating powerful waves called tsunamis.

answers.content: A cyclone
A drought

questions.question:
On the template provided, draw two tectonic plates converging.  
• Use arrows to show the direction each plate is moving.
• Label the place where earthquakes occur.
• Add a brief note explaining why shaking happens at this boundary.

answers.content: Student illustrates plates pushing together, arrows pointing inward, labels the fault zone/subduction zone, and notes that stress builds until rocks break, causing earthquakes.

questions.question: Why does Australia experience fewer major earthquakes than countries such as Japan?

answers.content: Australia sits near the middle of a tectonic plate, far from active plate boundaries where most earthquakes occur.
answers.explanation: Earthquake activity is greatest at plate margins; Australia is located on the stable interior of the Indo-Australian Plate.

questions.question: Which term describes liquid rock that flows out of a volcano during an eruption?

answers.content: Magma chamber
answers.explanation: A magma chamber is an underground pool of molten rock, not the liquid rock that reaches the surface.

answers.content: Lava
answers.explanation: Lava is molten rock that has reached Earth’s surface and flows from the volcano.

answers.content: Eruption
answers.explanation: An eruption is the event or process, not the liquid rock itself.

questions.question: Name one immediate change to the landscape that can occur during a volcanic eruption and describe a possible knock-on effect it may cause.

answers.content: Example answer: "A volcanic eruption can create new land when lava cools and hardens; consequently, the fertile soil that forms can support new plant growth."
answers.explanation: Award 1 mark for a correct immediate change (e.g., new land, ash covering, lava flow, crater formation) and up to 2 marks for a logical knock-on effect clearly linked with a causal connective (e.g., fertile soil, habitat loss, relocation of people).

questions.question: Most volcanoes form at the boundaries of what Earth structures?

answers.content: River deltas
answers.explanation: River deltas build up from sediment, not plate movement.

answers.content: Coral reefs
answers.explanation: Coral reefs are biological formations in shallow seas.

answers.content: Tectonic plates
answers.explanation: Movement where tectonic plates diverge or collide allows magma to reach the surface and form volcanoes.

answers.content: Sand dunes
answers.explanation: Sand dunes are wind-formed surface features, unrelated to magma.

questions.question: How can volcanic eruptions be constructive?

answers.content: They only destroy land and habitats.
answers.explanation: This ignores the constructive effects.

answers.content: They create fertile soils and new landforms.
answers.explanation: Ash and cooled lava break down into mineral-rich soils, and hardening lava adds new rock layers.

answers.content: They stop earthquakes from occurring.
answers.explanation: Volcanoes do not prevent earthquakes.

answers.content: They remove all gases from the atmosphere.
answers.explanation: Eruptions release, not remove, gases.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple cross-section of a volcano that shows: magma chamber, main vent, crater, and a lava flow on the surface.

answers.content: Exemplar drawing should include: 1) an underground magma chamber, 2) a vertical or near-vertical vent leading to the surface, 3) an opening/crater at the top, 4) lava flowing down the slope. Labels must be clear and correctly placed.
answers.explanation: Marking guide: 1 mark per correctly represented and labelled feature (4 marks total).

questions.question: The 79 AD eruption of Mount Vesuvius is valuable to archaeologists because:

answers.content: It created the tallest mountain in Italy.
answers.explanation: Vesuvius did not become Italy’s tallest mountain.

answers.content: Ash preserved the city of Pompeii, revealing details of Roman life.
answers.explanation: Buildings, artefacts and even food were sealed under ash, offering a time-capsule of ancient society.

answers.content: It stopped all volcanic activity in the Mediterranean.
answers.explanation: Volcanic activity continued in the region.

answers.content: Romans wrote the first volcano safety manual afterwards.
answers.explanation: No historical evidence supports this claim.

questions.question: In the classroom model, what represented the lava during the simulated eruption?

answers.content: The dry baking soda in the jar
answers.explanation: Baking soda alone did not flow from the ‘volcano.’

answers.content: The vinegar before mixing
answers.explanation: Vinegar alone did not resemble lava.

answers.content: The foamy mixture produced when vinegar and baking soda reacted
answers.explanation: The bubbling foam overflowed the jar, modelling flowing lava.

answers.content: The modelling clay around the jar
answers.explanation: The clay formed the mountain, not the lava.

questions.question: Write one well-structured paragraph that answers the focus question, “Do volcanoes create or destroy?”, using at least two causal connectives (for example: because, therefore, consequently). Your paragraph should include: • a clear argument • at least one example of constructive change • at least one example of destructive change.

answers.content: Sample response: "Volcanoes both create and destroy, because they can bury entire towns in ash yet form new, fertile land when the lava cools. For instance, Mount Vesuvius destroyed Pompeii; consequently, archaeologists learned a great deal about Roman life. At the same time, the rich volcanic soils around many active volcanoes support productive farms, therefore eruptions contribute to new life as well."
answers.explanation: Marking guide: 1 mark for clear stance, 1 mark each for a constructive and a destructive example, 2 marks for correct use of at least two causal connectives, 1 mark for overall coherence and paragraph structure.

questions.question: What is the best definition of weathering as studied in this lesson?

answers.content: The breaking down of rocks into smaller pieces by natural forces over time.
answers.explanation: Weathering refers to the gradual breakdown of rock; erosion is the transport of the pieces.

answers.content: The movement of broken rock fragments from one place to another.
answers.explanation: This is erosion, not weathering.

answers.content: The sudden melting of rock due to extreme heat.
Any change to Earth’s surface caused by humans.

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT identified as an agent of weathering in the interactive?

answers.content: Moving water
Wind
Plants
Lightning
answers.explanation: Lightning was not discussed as an agent of weathering in this lesson.

questions.question: In the sugar-cube (or soft-rock) investigation, what caused the cubes/rocks to weather?

answers.content: They dissolved in the air.
They knocked against each other while the jar was being shaken.
answers.explanation: Collisions chipped away small pieces, imitating natural abrasion.

answers.content: Heat from the students’ hands melted them.
Sunlight inside the jar dried them out.

questions.question: Describe how moving water can weather rocks. Use at least one causal connective (e.g., because, so, as a result).

answers.content: Flowing rivers, ocean waves and rain carry small particles that repeatedly hit rocks, so the rock surface wears away and becomes smoother over time.
answers.explanation: Answer shows cause (particles hitting) and effect (rock wears away) with a causal connective.

questions.question: Name two Australian landforms mentioned in the lesson that have been shaped by weathering and explain, in one sentence each, how weathering contributed to their formation.

answers.content: Example response: 1) Wave Rock – wind-blown sand gradually abraded the granite, creating its curved ‘wave’ shape. 2) Karlu Karlu (Devils Marbles) – temperature changes and water seepage fractured the granite boulders, causing the rounded blocks to separate.
answers.explanation: Any correct pair (e.g., Wave Rock and Karlu Karlu) with a brief weathering explanation earns full marks.

questions.question: Draw a labelled diagram that shows how plant roots can weather a rock. Include an arrow or sentence explaining the force the roots apply.

answers.content: Diagram includes: rock, growing root entering a crack, arrow showing outward pressure, label such as “root grows – pushes rock apart”, and brief explanation.
answers.explanation: Marks awarded for showing roots inside a crack, indicating force, and naming the process as weathering.

questions.question: What is erosion?

answers.content: The breaking of rocks into smaller pieces while they stay in place.
answers.explanation: That describes weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand from one place to another.
answers.explanation: Erosion moves the weathered material to a new location.

answers.content: The dropping or settling of sediment in a new place.
answers.explanation: That process is called deposition.

answers.content: The slow cooling of molten rock below Earth’s surface.
answers.explanation: That describes the formation of intrusive igneous rocks, not erosion.

questions.question: During the tray investigation, which tray is predicted to show the greatest amount of erosion?

answers.content: Tray 1 – flat surface
answers.explanation: The water flows slowly on a flat surface, producing less force.

answers.content: Tray 2 – gentle slope (one book)
answers.explanation: A gentle slope increases speed a little, but not as much as a steep slope.

answers.content: Tray 3 – steep slope (three books)
answers.explanation: The steep slope makes the water flow fastest, giving it the greatest force to move sand.

answers.content: All trays will experience the same amount of erosion
answers.explanation: Changing the slope changes the force of the water, so results will differ.

questions.question: Explain why water flowing down a steeper slope causes more erosion than water flowing down a flat surface.

answers.content: On a steeper slope the water accelerates, moving faster. Faster-moving water has greater kinetic energy and therefore greater force. This extra force can pick up and carry more particles of sand and soil, resulting in increased erosion.

questions.question: In the fair-test investigation, which single variable is intentionally changed?

answers.content: Amount of water poured
answers.explanation: The same volume of water should be used each time.

answers.content: Slope (angle) of the tray
answers.explanation: Only the slope is altered to test its effect on erosion.

answers.content: Type of tray material
answers.explanation: All trays are identical.

answers.content: Amount of sand in the tray
answers.explanation: Each tray contains the same amount of sand.

questions.question: List two natural forces other than moving water that can cause erosion and give one example landform created by each.

answers.content: Wind – example: formation of The Pinnacles in Western Australia.  Ice (glaciers) – example: U-shaped valleys carved in the Alps.

questions.question: After materials are eroded they are often dropped in a new place. What is this process called?

answers.content: Sedimentation
answers.explanation: Close, but the specific term taught was deposition.

answers.content: Deposition
answers.explanation: Deposition is the dropping or settling of eroded material.

answers.content: Subsidence
answers.explanation: Subsidence refers to ground sinking, not to dropping sediment.

answers.content: Compaction
answers.explanation: Compaction happens after deposition, when sediments are pressed together.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram of one of your trays after the investigation. Show the river path, areas where sand was removed and where it was deposited. Include arrows to indicate water flow direction.
